questions.text: A woman has mild depressive symptoms after few days of delivery which disappears within 2 weeks of the postpartum period. The most likely cause is ______
questions.solution:
The patient has mild depressive symptoms after a few days of delivery which resolved spontaneously; this is characteristic of postpartum blues.

During this period the patient may experience mood lability, sadness, dysphoria, subjective confusion, and tearfulness.

These feelings have been ascribed to rapid changes in women's hormonal levels, the stress of childbirth, and the awareness of the increased responsibility that motherhood brings. This usually resolve spontaneously. 

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: Where are owl's eye inclusion bodies seen?
questions.solution:
Owl’s eye inclusion bodies are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.

Cytomegalovirus is a type of herpes virus, which causes severe disease in immunocompromised patients. In most other cases, it is inapparent and marked by prolonged latency with intermittent reactivation.

Diagnosis:

  • IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV). 
  • Avidity level measured by avidity index is used to describe the percentage of IgG bound to the antigen after being treated with denaturing agents.These assays are based on the fact that low avidity IgG antibodies are present during the first few months after the infection and avidity increases over time indicating maturation of the immune response. So the presence of high avidity IgG denotes a past infection rather than a primary one. Low avidity IgG signals a primary infection within the last 3-4 months. 
  • IgM detection can be used as an indicator of acute infection, but it lacks specificity for primary infection. This is because it persists for years in some individuals and is also produced during reactivation.

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV). The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia. 

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

1. Bacterial Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Bacteria  Inclusion bodies 
Granuloma inguinale, Klebsiella granulomatis Donovan bodies
Psittacosis, Chlamydia psittacci  Levinthal-Cole-Lille bodies (LCL bodies)

Lymphogranuloma venereum, Chlamydia trachomatis Miyagawa’s granulocorpusles
Diphtheria, Corynebacterium diptheriae Babes-Ernst granules

 

2. Viral Inclusion Bodies

  • Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies

Variola (smallpox) Paschen bodies
Molluscum contagiosum Henderson-Patterson bodies
Fowlpox Bollinger bodies
  • Intra-nuclear Inclusion Bodies 
  Inclusion bodies  Disease/Virus

Acidophilic inclusions Poliovirus
  • Both Intra-nuclear and Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies

Measles Virus Warthin-Finkedly giant cells
Cytomegalovirus Owl-eye inclusions (basophilic, predominantly intra-nuclear, small granular intracytoplasmic inclusions are found)

 

3. Inclusion Bodies in Parasitic Infections

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the hospital for the management of breast cancer. The tumor is 3 cm in size with ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes. There is no distant metastasis. The TNM staging of the tumor is:
questions.solution:
The TNM staging of the tumor is T2 N1 M0.

  • Tumor size 3 cm: T2 
  • Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes: N1
  • No distant metastasis: M0

Points to remember

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm).
  • Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Tumor (T) Description
Tis Ductal carcinoma in situ / Paget's disease
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – inflammatory breast carcinoma(typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
Metastasis absent M0
Metastasis present M1

  

Stages       T , N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

 M0
Stage IV

Any T, Any N

 M1

#Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of chest wall.

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: An HIV-positive individual presents with the following. What is the diagnosis &  WHO clinical stage of HIV?
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis (Thrush) is characterized in WHO Clinical Stage 3.

Oral Candidiasis (Thrush), and oral hairy leukoplakia, are oral lesions characterized in WHO clinical Stage 3. They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL.

Differentiating oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia:

  • Oral Candidiasis (Thrush) appears as a white, cheesy exudate, on an erythematous mucosa in the posterior oropharynx. The diagnosis is made by direct examination of pseudohyphal elements.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia presents as white, frondlike lesions, generally along the lateral borders of the tongue and sometimes on the adjacent buccal mucosa(image below). Despite its name, oral hairy leukoplakia is not considered premalignant. Lesions are associated with Ebstein barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: Severe degree of anemia in pregnancy is defined as Hb ______
questions.solution:
Severe Anemia is classified as Hb < 7 g/dL.

ICMR classification of anemia in pregnancy :

Mild anemia

10–10.9 g%

Moderate anemia

7–9.9 g%

Severe anemia

< 7 g%

Very severe anemia

< 4 g%

WHO definition of Anemia:

Pregnancy State Normal (g/dL) Mild (g/dL) Moderate (g/dL) Severe (g/dL)
First Trimester 11 or higher 10-10.9 7-9.9 <7
Second Trimester 10.5 or higher
Third trimester 11 or higher 10-10.9 7-9.9 <7

questions.text: Staging laparotomy was performed in a woman who presented with an adnexal mass. On histopathological examination, you see the below finding. This finding is associated with?
questions.solution:
The image shows the characteristic Schiller Duval's body. It is seen in the endodermal sinus tumor (yolk sac tumor).

It is usually unilateral and highly malignant. Histological features reveals cystic spaces lined by flattened epithelium. Vascular tufts are seen within the space - Schiller Duval body. These tumors are usually associated with raised AFP and alpha 1 antitrypsin.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Associated feature

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma - Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Remember:

Dysgerminoma

(Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP
  • L: LDH

questions.text: All the following are true about subconjunctival hemorrhage except ______.

choices.text: It can occur spontaneously in elder people with systolic hypertension.
The blood gets absorbed gradually in 6-8 weeks time without treatment.
Use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

questions.solution:
The blood gets absorbed gradually in 1-3 weeks time without treatment, not 6-8 weeks.

Subconjunctival hemorrhage

  • It is also called as subconjunctival ecchymosis.
  • It is due to the rupture of small blood vessels.
  • It can occur spontaneously in elder people with systolic hypertension or after local trauma.
  • If the posterior limit is not seen, check for the base of skull fracture. 
  • Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukemia. The differential diagnosis includes Kaposi sarcoma.
  • Blood gradually changes color and resolves in 1-3 weeks time.
  • The use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

questions.text: Which of the following pathway is the most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver?
questions.solution:
The most important source of reducing equivalents (NADPH) for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (HMP).

Since HMP shunt pathway and fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. This NADPH is involved as a donor of reducing equivalents in both the reduction of the 3-ketoacyl and of the 2,3-unsaturated acyl derivatives. 

Other sources are:

  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

Related Pearl: Reducing Equivalents and Their Uses

Reducing agents

Uses

NADPH

Lipid synthesis

Cholesterol synthesis 

Fatty acid chain elongation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylation of aromatic compounds, steroids, alcohols, and drugs

NADH

Metabolizes alcohol

Glycolysis & Krebs cycle

Oxidative phosphorylation

β- Oxidation of fatty acid

Catalyzes reactions in muscle and liver cells

Electron Transport Chain

FADH2

Krebs cycle

Electron Transport Chain

Oxidative Phosphorylation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylase cycle

β-Oxidation of fatty acid

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of Guillian-Barre syndrome (GBS)?
questions.solution:
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common type of GBS.

There are several types of Guillain–Barre syndrome, which are recognized by electrodiagnostic studies and pathological distinctions. These include:

A. Demyelinating

  • Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) [Most common]

B. Axonal

  • Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN)
  • Acute motor–sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN)

C. Regional GBS syndromes

  • Miller–Fisher syndrome (MFS)
  • Pure sensory forms
  • Ophthalmoplegia with anti-GQ1b antibodies as part of severe motor-sensory GBS
  • GBS with severe bulbar and facial paralysis
  • Acute pandysautonomia

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: All of the following structures pass through both greater and lesser sciatic foramen except _______
questions.solution:
The Tendon of the obturator internus muscle passes only through the lesser sciatic foramen.

Structures passing through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramen:

  • Pudendal nerve
  • Nerve to obturator internus
  • Internal pudendal vessels

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramen

Structures passing through the Greater Sciatic Foramen

The piriformis, emerging from the pelvis, it fills the foramen almost completely and is the key muscle of the region.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the Lesser Sciatic Foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: Which of the following  acts as the primary trigger for onset of labour in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
The fetal ACTH causes an increase in estrogen acting as the onset of labour in pregnant women. It results in the growth of the fetal adrenal gland which has the capacity for steroid biosynthesis i.e. estrogen.

Daily steroid production of fetal adrenal glands near term is more than in adults.

questions.text: A 2 year old boy presenting with diarrhoea is irritable and drinks fluids eagerly when given. According to IMNCI, which of the following is the best suited treatment plan ?
questions.solution:
The clinical signs and symptoms of the above child signifies some dehydration. According to IMNCI, children with some dehydration or moderate dehydration should be treated with Plan B. 

In Plan B, fluid requirement (given orally) is calculated as :

  • Daily fluid requirement : Holliday Segar method
    Weight Quantity of fluids
    Upto 10 kg  100 ml/kg
    10-20 kg 1000 ml + 50ml/kg for every kg above 10 kg
    >20 kg 1500 ml + 20ml/kg for every kg above 20 kg
     
  • Deficit replacement or rehydration therapy - 75ml/kg of ORS over 4 hours
  • Maintenance therapy - Replace every stool with 10ml/kg of ORS after signs of dehydration disappear

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A salivary gland tumor with a propensity for perineural invasion is _______.
questions.solution:
A salivary gland tumour with a propensity for perineural invasion is adenoid cystic carcinoma.

Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a slow-growing malignant tumour of major and minor salivary glands. It is composed of both epithelial and myoepithelial cells. It is the second most common malignant tumour of the parotid gland. The histologic types of adenoid cystic carcinoma are tubular, cribriform, and solid. The tubular type has the best prognosis, while the solid type has the worst. 

Adenoid cystic carcinoma has propensity for perineural invasion. Patients will present with slow-growing masses, with the presence of numbness, paraesthesia or pain. Treatment is the removal of the gross tumor, with radiation therapy for the microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Investigation of choice in evaluation of posterior urethral valve ______
questions.solution:
• Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG)/MCU is the best imaging technique for the diagnosis of posterior urethral valves. The diagnosis is best made during the micturition phase in lateral or oblique views, such that the posterior urethra can be imaged adequately.
  • Findings include:
    • Dilatation and elongation of the posterior urethra (the equivalent of the ultrasonographic keyhole sign)
    • The linear radiolucent band corresponding to the valve (only occasionally seen)
    • Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR): Seen in 50% of patients
    • Bladder trabeculation/ diverticula

The image depicts MCU showing dilated posterior urethra in posterior urethral valve.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was asked to blow-off a paper repeatedly while doing an EEG. The recording shows symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begins and ends suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a child with a 3Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG, which was provoked by hyperventilation, suggests a diagnosis of absence seizures.

Absence seizures are the most common seizures in children. The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharge pattern.

These seizures are characterized by a sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and without post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. The patient presents with subtle, bilateral motor signs such as rapid blinking of the eyelids, chewing movements, or small-amplitude, clonic movements of the hands. These can occur hundreds of times in a day. The child is often misunderstood to be 'daydreaming' and parents are often told that there is a decline in the child's performance at school.

The first line treatment drugs for absent seizures include valproic acid, ethosuximide and lamotrigine. 

Other options:

Option A: Generalised tonic-clonic seizure is characterized by tonic contractions of muscles followed by periods of muscle relaxation (clonic phase). It is associated with unresponsiveness, muscular flaccidity, excessive salivation, and incontinence. The EEG is characterized by an increase in generalized low-voltage fast waves after which generalized high-amplitude, polyspike discharges in the tonic phase. In the clonic phase, a spike and slow-wave pattern are observed. 

Option B: Atonic seizures are characterized by sudden loss of postural muscle tone. Consciousness may not be impaired and postictal confusion is not usually present. The EEG shows generalized spike-wave discharge followed by diffuse slow waves which correspond to the muscle tone. 

Option D: Myoclonic seizures are characterized by sudden and brief contraction of part of or the entire body. The EEG shows synchronous spike-and-slow-wave discharges just before the onset of myoclonic movements.

questions.text: Which is the study design of choice to identify the prevalence of a disease?
questions.solution:
Cross-sectional study is done to identify the prevalence of a disease.

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

 

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Other options:
Option B: An ambispective cohort is the combination of both retrospective and prospective cohort studies.
Option C: In a case-control study, the study begins from the outcome and goes retrospectively to find out the exposure among the cases and controls.
Option D: In case of a prospective cohort study, the study population is followed up regularly to look for the effects of exposure. 

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

Incidence in Epidemiology:

  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Incidence = (Number of cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time) x 1000
  • Incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year.
  • It provides insight into the effectives of health services and programs.
  • Incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000
  • It is generally used for acute illnesses.
  • Special types of incidence rates:
    • Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.
    • Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.
  • Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Prevalence in Epidemiology:

  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio.
  • It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.
  • Types:
    • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
  • Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.
  • Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100
  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

  • Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.
  • Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration
  • Longer the duration of the disease, greater the prevalence.
  • In acute diseases,because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence.This is because in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as duration of disease decreases.
  • If treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Energy requirement in pregnancy for a moderate worker is:
questions.solution:
A woman doing moderate work requires 2130 kcal and in pregnancy an additional 350 kcal is needed.

Hence, the total requirement for a moderately working pregnant woman is 2480 kcal. Therefore, the most probable answer among the given options is 2500 kcal.

Dietary Reference Intakes

  • Recommeneded Dietary Allowance (RDA) - The average daily dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all induviduals in a group
  • Estimated Average Requirement (EAR) - A nutrient intake value that is estimated to meet the requirements of half the induviduals in a group

Note: There is no RDA for energy. The EAR is equivalent to Estimated Energy Requirement (EER).

The Estimated Average Requirement for an elderly male (>60 years) is 1700 Kcal/D and for an elderly female (>60 years), it is 1500 Kcal/D.

questions.text: The antimicrobial treatment initiated in a patient who is not yet infected is called as____________.
questions.solution:
The antimicrobial treatment initiated in a patient who is not yet infected is called as prophylactic therapy. The goal is to prevent infection in some patients and to prevent dangerous manifestations of infections in other patients. 

Preemptive therapy: Therapy in an asymptomatic individual with evidence of infection (high-risk).

Empirical therapy: Broad therapy in a patient with symptoms of infection but no microbiological confirmation of the causative agent. 

Definitive therapy: Definite therapy directed against microbiologically confirmed microbes with sensitive agents.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency with a painful scrotum. On examination, the patient is febrile and a Prehn’s sign is positive. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute epididymitis. 

A positive Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymis from testicular torsion. A Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis. If it persists, it is likely to be testicular torsion.

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually active males. In older men(>40yrs) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results from urinary infection, most commonly due to Escherichia coli.

Acute epididymitis is managed by antibiotics and scrotal support.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented after an episode of acute gastroenteritis and was infused with fluids. A while later, after fluid infusion, his heart rate rose to 122 bpm and he complained of palpitations. The presence of tachycardia can be explained by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The presence of tachycardia can be explained by the Bainbridge reflex.

It is a compensatory cardiac reflex where there is an increase in the heart rate in response to raised atrial stretch.

In fluid overload states, commonly after excessive fluid infusion, there is distension of the atria due to increased blood volume. This distension activates the atrial stretch receptors which transmit the afferent signals to the medulla via the vagus nerve. The efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves. This leads to an increase in the strength of contraction of the heart and tachycardia. This reflex helps in preventing excess accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and in the pulmonary circulation.

Other options - 

Option A: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region. They can be elicited after administering certain irritants like capsaicin or serotonin. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography. This reflex is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. 

Option B: Pulmonary chemoreflex is due to the stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) which are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung. This produces reflex apnea followed by a rapid increase in breathing rate, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Option D: Cushing's reflex is seen when the intracranial pressure is raised where the blood supply to ventrolateral medulla neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia stimulate the neurons producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

*Note: Bainbridge reflex causes tachycardia, whereas all the other mentioned reflexes predominately cause bradycardia.

questions.text: Increased callus formation is seen in:
questions.solution:
Increased callus formation is seen with flexibly fixed fractures. 

Fracture heals through direct union (primary bone healing) or by callus formation (secondary bone healing).

  • Direct union: This occurs when the fracture site is absolutely stable. This is seen in a fracture held by a metal plate with absolute stability and in cases of impacted fracture in cancellous bones. There is no stimulus for callus formation. Osteoblastic new bone formation occurs directly between the fracture fragments.
  • Callus formation: This occurs when the fracture is not fixed rigidly. The healing proceeds through 5 stages: hematoma formation, inflammation, soft callus formation, hard callus formation, and remodelling.

questions.text: Dissociative anesthesia is a characteristic feature of _______
questions.solution:
Ketamine produces dissociative anesthesia which is characterized by a state wherein the patient is conscious (eg., eye opening, swallowing, muscle contracture) but unable to process or respond to sensory input.

It acts as an antagonist at the phencyclidine site of the NMDA receptor.

Ketamine functionally “dissociates” the thalamus (which relays sensory impulses from the reticular activating system to the cerebral cortex) from the limbic cortex (which is involved with the awareness of sensation).

Though the patient may have intact corneal, cough, and swallow reflexes, they need not be protective.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man who is a chronic alcoholic has the following hepatitis B profile:
HBs Ag positive, HBe Ag positive, declining IgM anti-HBc in the presence of rising total anti-HBc.
What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this case is chronic infective hepatitis.

HBsAg positive suggests active infection.

HBeAg positive signifies continued viral replication, high infectivity, and probable progression to chronic hepatitis.

Declining IgM anti-HBc in the presence of rising total anti-HBc indicates IgM being converted to IgG and hence the infection is chronic.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

  HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc
Acute HBV, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM

Acute HBV-Window period

-

 - +/- +/- IgM
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG
Recovery - + - +/- IgG

Immunization with HBsAg

 - + - - -

questions.text: While performing a PET-CT scan, uptake in which of the following areas is likely to be a false positive?
questions.solution:
On 18F-FDG PET-CT scan, the urinary bladder shows normal physiological uptake and is a potential source of false-positive in oncologic imaging. 

The following are areas of normal physiological uptake on PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract - intestinal wall
  • Genitourinary tract - as FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems
  • Brown fat - FDG accumulates here as glucose and ATP are required for heat production
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

The following image shows supraclavicular uptake on a PET scan, due to the presence of brown adipose tissue.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and pain in the right iliac fossa. He had a history of nausea and vomiting 3 days back and was not taken to the hospital. The surgeon suggested percutaneous drainage as the CT of the right iliac fossa showed a well-circumscribed fluid collection.  What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
The history of right iliac fossa pain with fever, nausea, and vomiting is suggestive of acute appendicitis, which in this case has progressed to an appendicular abscess as suggested by the radiological findings.

An appendicular abscess is a very common complication of an untreated or perforated appendix. It can occur retroperitoneally or intraperitoneally.

Investigations include USG or CT of the abdomen which shows a well-circumscribed, rounded, or ill-defined, irregular fluid collection in the appendicular region. 

With the recent advances, early laparoscopic drainage or radiologically assisted percutaneous drainage followed by delayed appendicectomy is also done. If these are unsuccessful or there is leakage into the peritoneal cavity a midline laparotomy can be done. 

Note:

The popular management of an appendicular mass is the Oschner-Sherren regime which is conservative management as the inflammatory process has already been localized and surgery is complicated now. 

If it progresses to an abscess, it must be drained radiologically or laparoscopically along with intravenous antibiotics.

The indications for stopping the conservative management include:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain 
  • The increasing size of the mass.

A follow-up CT is taken in case of conservative management to ensure that there is a complete resolution of the inflammatory process.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy, who is a football player, comes to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football on the ground. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding as well as unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is shown below. What is the sign shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the Holman-Miller sign or antral sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here. the tumor grows into the

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Other options:

Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in glomus tumor, when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus—antral sign or Holman-Miller sign

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents 3 days after an episode of unprotected intercourse. He complains of profuse purulent discharge per urethra and severe burning pain on passing urine. Which of the following is a probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical picture suggests a diagnosis of gonorrhoea as the patient presents with purulent discharge within the incubation period of gonorrhoea (2–7 days).

  • In men, gonorrhoea usually presents with acute dysuria with profuse purulent discharge per urethra.
  • The primary site of infection in women is the cervix but the urethra, rectum and pharynx may be involved. Symptomatic infections manifest as excessive vaginal discharge, dysuria, deep dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding and intermenstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with dizziness and palpitations following an alcohol binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ECG are suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

The ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves which are the features suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation is a supraventricular tachycardia caused by ectopic foci or small reentry circuits within the atria. It has an atrial rate of 400-600/min and a ventricular rate of 100-160/min. The incidence of AF increases with age and is usually associated with an acute precipitating factor such as acute alcohol intoxication.

questions.text: A person presents to the emergency department with suspected poisoning due to ingestion of arsenic containing pesticides 24 hours ago. Which of the following is not a likely finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Mees lines are unlikely to be found in a patient with arsenic ingestion 24 hours ago. 

Features of acute arsenic poisoning

  • Acute toxicity typically starts in the gastrointestinal system with severe watery diarrhea (like cholera)
  • QTc prolongation and cardiac arrhythmias
  • Acute encephalopathy
  • Renal injury with Acute Tubular Necrosis
  • Garlic odor of breath and stools

Mees lines (horizontal 1 to 2 mm white lines on the nails, also called transverse leukonychia), which occur from a disturbance in the nail matrix keratinization. It usually takes at least 30 days for the Mees lines to become visible. It may be seen 4 to 6 weeks after an acute arsenic ingestion. These can also be seen in Thallium poisoning.

Mees' lines:

questions.text: Slow sand filters are also called _________
questions.solution:
• Slow sand filters are also called biological filters.

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of the filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts like a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer which contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed are kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scrapping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.
